content.html: thanks, I'll keep this in mind for the ignition pull request

update.description:
This is a new math class called SignalStats that computes incremental statistics on signals (see [gazebo_design document](#!/osrf/gazebo_design/src/default/signal_stats/signal_stats.md) for more detail). I used this extensively for the accuracy tests and refined the API to minimize the lines of code required for implementation. I think it can be useful in integration tests as well and have converted the `INTEGRATION_physics_inertia_ratio` test as an example. It's especially useful in reducing console spam by replacing expectations inside of loops with a single expectation outside the loop.

I will make a separate pull request to ignition-math.
update.title: New math class SignalStats

content.raw:
I think I wrote this after watching the [video of Herb Sutter talking about Modern C++](http://channel9.msdn.com/Events/Build/2014/2-661), specifically talking about data structures and how arrays / vectors work very well with pre-fetching.

I didn't do any profiling, but my assumption in the design document (inspired by performance testing) is that InsertData is called frequently during a time-sensitive loop, while GetMap is called less frequently outside the time-sensitive loop. That inspired me to use vectors for the data structures that would be used by InsertData.

That's my rationale, but I'm open to feedback on the topic.
content.html:
I think I wrote this after watching the video of Herb Sutter talking about Modern C++, specifically talking about data structures and how arrays / vectors work very well with pre-fetching.

I didn't do any profiling, but my assumption in the design document (inspired by performance testing) is that InsertData is called frequently during a time-sensitive loop, while GetMap is called less frequently outside the time-sensitive loop. That inspired me to use vectors for the data structures that would be used by InsertData.

That's my rationale, but I'm open to feedback on the topic.

content.raw:
Technically you could have different numbers of data points if you call InsertStatistic after InsertData. It's not how I expect the class to be used, but I wanted to accurately describe what the function does.

I guess I'll add this comment to the doxygen for this function.
content.html:
Technically you could have different numbers of data points if you call InsertStatistic after InsertData. It's not how I expect the class to be used, but I wanted to accurately describe what the function does.

I guess I'll add this comment to the doxygen for this function.

content.html: The math functions don't have access to gazebo::common::Console. Should I do std::cerr instead?

content.raw: Maybe it would be interesting to use a map instead of a vector. You would simplify the GetMap() function (or maybe you don't need it anymore). There's also performance considerations but I don't think we plan to store a lot of statistics inside `stats`.
content.html: Maybe it would be interesting to use a map instead of a vector. You would simplify the GetMap() function (or maybe you don't need it anymore). There's also performance considerations but I don't think we plan to store a lot of statistics inside stats.
